text.p: These are the leading stories in the Maltese press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Rezaq sentenced to life in prison. Omar Mohammed Ali Rezaq, a Palestinian raised in a refugee camp, was jailed for life by a Washington court on Monday after leading the hijacking of an Egyptair aircaft to Malta in 1985. He was found guilty of shooting two passengers, an American and an Israeli, at point blank range. Nearly 60 passengers died when Egyptian commandos stormed the plane.
- Labour leader Alfred Sant says Malta facing growing crisis of values. Sant told a televised press conference that the values of solidarity and cooperation were being lost to consumerism.

- Labour Party boosts campaign promise to remove VAT, insisting the October 26 election is the one and only chance for voters to reverse VAT. The opposition Labour Party has promised to remove it, replacing it with customs duties which were in force in 1994. A shortfall in revenue will be made up for by a reduction of government spending on "excesses".

- Fenech Adami given warm welcome in Zetjun. Prime Minister Eddie Fenech Adami held an outdoor meeting in Zetjun, a Labour Party stronghold where the police in 1987 used tear gas to prevent Nationalist Party supporters from holding a meeting in the dying days of the Labour government.
